Half the city block = A/2 = 45000 square feet

Once upon a time, there was a lonely, lonely boy.  All this boy had ever wanted was a friend, a true friend that would stay and tolerate his actions until the ultimate end of death.  He searched far and wide to find this friend, but was unable to find anyone who wanted to stay with him until the end of eternity.  The boy was so downtrodden that he acquired genital cancer of the highest degree.  While in the hospital, alone and without any true friends to visit him in his sickly and weakening state, the boy comtemplated on this actions and also on his personality in order to discover why it was that he could find no true friends.  Finally he came to a conclusion.  He realized that he did not have enough swag to be considered a friend of anyone.  Therefore, the little boy, still affected by the symptoms of his cancer and its treatments, ventured off to the North in order to freeze himself to death, and end that would guarentee a quick and painless death as the cold numbs all senses.  However, as he sat in the freezing temperatures and on the verge of death, a narwhal climbs out of the water and rushes to the boy to save his life, warming him with the fat on his body.  It was there that the boy found his true friend, a buddy that would put everything on the line in order to save him from death.  The two experienced a bond like no other and skipped off into the sunset arm-in-arm.  BUT, the boy was still not satisfied with his friend as he was still unable to fully live in complete synergy with the narwhal.  Therefore, the boy made his final decision.  He cut off all of his limbs and duct taped them all into one, long horn with which he sewed onto his forehead.  By doing so, the boy had finally reached coexistence with the narwhal and the two lived happily ever after.

It has been given that a gallon of water has the potential to cover 13.8 square feet of the ground, and that the typical block surrounding the mall is roughly 300 feet by 300 feet. 300 square feet x 150 square feet = 45,000 square feet available in half a city block.

THE ANSWER

    It is not correct because the newscaster, Ida Individual, never graduated high school!

    Ida Fallower, as she was named in her youth, was born in 1979 in the small town of Alwayza of  Guinea Pig County, Oklahoma. She, along with her three older brothers, worked on the Fallower family farm in their childhood. They had a heck of a time , always getting through the hard work with the love and support they and their parents had for one another. Everyone in the family surprisingly got along. No one did anything unusual or different. "We were like peas and carrots" Ida once said in an interview for the Nevabea Times. Though the good times didn't last forever...

    Ida enjoyed the farm life, though she found it quite predictable and boring. Occasionally every few months or so they would get deliveries from the factories in Nevebea, the big city in Guinea Pig County, but that was all the excitement she ever felt inside herself in those days.

    When Ida turned sixteen years old, she told her family she had an announcement to make.

    "I love all of you, and I love living with you guys. However, I cannot stay on the farm forever." The Fallower family, which was eating supper at sunset like any ordinary, turned their heads from their meal at once, as if they were controlled with strings by a puppeteer.

    After the shock of change went away from the five, Ida explained how even though the Fallower family had been living on that farm for generations, she just couldn't take the idea of living their forever. She wanted to move to the big city, Nevebea. While she would still miss them, she would be able to visit them on holidays since, afterall, she was still within the boundry lines of Guinea Pig County.  Her parents refused to accept her reasonable ideas and sent her to her room, using the same punishments that all the Fallower's endured when they did something "bad" for generations. However, it didn't work on Ida. She used her brain, thought for herself, and used a rope to sneak out from her second story window. It was last the Fallower's saw her until Ida's wedding day.

   While in Nevebea, Ida was determined to succeed on her own through lower, menial jobs as she worked her way through the ranks. Eventually she was able to become a newscaster for the Channel

69 News. She also found love, got married, changed her name to Ida Individual, and lived happily ever after. While the Fallower family died during a tornado.

THE END

Therefore 90,000 needs to be cut in half; giving us 45,000 square feet. We then need to divide the 45,000 square feet by the square feet of gallons that the water/ coffee could plausibly occupy-- 13.8 square feet.  From doing so, the answer we get is  3,260 gallons of water/ coffee. The newscaster's claim is incorrect because the amount of coffee that would cover half of the city block would actually be about 1/8 of the average city block, not half.

 

To find this amount, I multiplied the 13.8 square feet value of the gallon of water by the 400 gallons of coffee held in the fountain, which is 5520. Then, I multiplied 300 by 300, for the total length of an average city block, which is 90,000, but since the newscaster claimed the spilled coffee would cover half of a block, I cut 90,000 in half, bringing it to 45,000.

 

Finally, I divided 5520 by 45,000 and reached a total percentage of about 12.3%, which is almost the same as the percentage of 1/8 (12.5%).

Assuming the coffee cup holds 400 gallons of coffee, if it broke it would cover the equivalent of less than half of a city block. One gallon of water covers 13.8 square feet, and each city block adjacent to the mall is about 300 feet by 300 feet. The area of a whole city block is 300 x 300 = 90000 square feet, and half that area is 90000 divided by 2, which equals 45000 square feet. So this is the area the newscaster claims would be covered by a spill of 400 gallons of coffee. However, with the knowledge that one gallon of liquid covers about 13.8 square feet, we can multiply this number times 400 to produce the number of square feet that would be covered if all 400 gallons of coffee spilled: 5520 square feet. Half a city block is 45000 square feet, but the area that would be covered by such a spill is 39480 feet short of covering half of a city block.

The newscaster's report is actually incorrect. When looking at the data we have we know that since one city block is 300 feet by 300 feet, the area of one entire city block will be 90,000 square feet. In order to find the amount of gallons it would take to cover the entire city block, we must divide the area of the city block by the amount of gallons that would cover that area, which would turn out to be 6,522 gallons. But since we want to know how much water covers half of the city block, we divide the amount of gallons needed to cover the area of the city block by 2, which ends up being 3261 gallons. Now that we have an accurate value for the amount of gallons of water needed to cover half a city block, it is clear that the newscaster's report was incorrect because 400 gallons of water would only cover about 5,520 square feet whereas half of the city block is actualy 45,000 square feet.

Karissa held her sword tightly against her as her white steed raced forward. Sweat and blood trinkled down her face, but she didn't care. This was it. This was the last one, and if she wouldn't fail. Bryce, on his black steed, raced down the hill right by her side. The army followed behind them shouting and yelling. Karissa marveled at their bravery. They were pretty much running to their deaths, and yet they remained loyal to her and to Bryce, and did not give up or run away. The dark enemy was laid spread out in front of them. Their spears came forward to protect themselves, and she heard one of their captains shout a releasing order. "Arrows!" she called to her The thuds of the arrows came down. She held her shield over her head to protect herself. The enemy now lay only a few yards infront of her. This is it, she said to herself again. She would not fail. She could not fail. She swung her heavy sword, breaking the forming line of the enemy. Her army had the advantage of the horses, which trampled over the bodies of the enemy below. She fought like a madwoman, using all of her strength in every swing. She brought down two or three enemies with each blow. Suddenly, something from behind her grabbed her and pulled her off her horse. She fell to the ground with a thud, but was quickly on her feet again to face an enormous, heavy man. He looked like a bear, in Karissa's opinion. His face was covered with thick black hair, and his skin was incredibly dark. He flashed a white smirk down at her. He held an enormous axe in one hand, and a monstrous sword in the other. "Time to die," he said, then lifted his sword to make a swing. She ducked out of the way, rolling in between his legs and standing up behind him. As he was turning around, she drove her sword into the back of his neck. He screeched, then fell to the ground, dead. On the ground, Karissa found more and more pursuers, but she killed them off easily. She continued to fight for what seemed hours. When the sun was beginning to set, Karissa found herself becoming very weak. Blood trickled down her face, down her arms, everywhere that skin was exposed. Sweat spilled into the cuts, bringing a sharp pain to the wounds Karissa had obtained. A loud shout came from the east. She turned to see, and her heart dropped. It was him. It was the one who started all of this, and who had caused her so much pain, and he was coming right for her. A smile flashed across his face. "Well well well, we meet again." Karissa spat at his feet, glaring up into his evil eyes. "Any last words, Karissa my sweet?" Karissa raised her sword. "My words will be the last words you ever get to hear," she growled. He laughed, then suddenly lunged forward toward her. She blocked his blow with her sword, and shoved him backward, but he pursued again. Over and over he pursued, and she blocked. Her arms were beginning to ache, and he seemed to come at her with full energy and strength. She had been confident before, but now, she didn't know if she could do it. Just as she thought this, he swiped a blow at the back of her legs, knocking her to her knees. He grabbed her arms and knocked the sword out of her hand. He then placed his sword against her neck. "You might as well just admit it, you will always lose." He moved his sword to finish her off. Karissa shut her eyes, but the blow never came. She opened one eye to see a headless man standing infront of her. She cringed backward and jumped to her feet. The headless body fell to the ground. Behind the body was Bryce. He looked down at the body in disgust, bloodied sword raised. He then looked up at Karissa. "Are you alright?" he asked her. She couldn't say anything. She just ran up to him and wrapped grateful arms around him. She didn't know why, but tears began to form in her eyes. "You saved me," she whispered against his neck. "I'll always be here to save you," he whispered in her ear, then placed a kiss on her neck. "Captain!" a voice sounded. Both Karissa and Bryce looked in the direction of the voice. It was one of their leaders. "We have victory!" he shouted. They looked around to see that the enemy had surrendered. They had did so when Bryce cut off the head of their leader. Karissa breathed a sigh of relief. She had did it. She had won.
